title: How would you compare Slash with Eddie Van Halen? Who's better and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Slash to me was impressive during GNR’s early days, but in the long run he seemed to be a bit of a Jimmy Page rip off (please, no smart arse comments about ‘Page-ripped-off-every-song’; that’s too passe & monotonous). Eddie van Halen was a bit more aggressive when he burst onto the scene - of course, spawning a legion of imitators (even though he was known for his ability to play Clapton solos note-for-note before widespread fame, it’s recently come to my attention that a certain Page guitar solo inspired him to embark on his well-known finger tapping technique). Also, rhythmically he has a funk feel that I don’t hear from Mr. Slash - not any GNR songs I’ve heard, anyway (“Patience” is just pedestrian acoustic guitar playing). I don’t feel comfortable enough to answer “who’s better”, but given the aforementioned song - EvH has more of an edge with his clean guitar playing - while not quite acoustic, it’s the next best thing - on “Finish What Ya Started”. Apart from they’re both different guitarists (even though I tacitly implied EvH was better). For what it’s worth, Slash (Saul Hudson) was born in England to an African-American mother & an English father. He originally decided to take up the bass, but chose guitar when he heard his teacher play “Brown Sugar”. Eddie van Halen (Edward Lodewijk van Halen; wikipedia is inconsistent; “van” with upper & lowercase), on the other hand was born to an East Indies-born (Eurasian) mother & a Dutch father some 10 years earlier in Holland. Along with his brother, he learned to play piano at age 6, before deciding to take up drums - until he realised his brother was more suited to the instrument/s.

Slash is a very good blues-based guitar player who wrote great riffs and solos. In the imaginary book, “The History of Rock Guitar,” Slash gets a page because GNR pushed hair metal into a coffin that Nirvana nailed shut. But the 90’s were not dominated by Slash wannabes. Eddie reconceived how we hear and play the instrument. An entire decade of players were measured against the yardstick Eddie created. And that hair metal sound GNR helped kill? It grew from the seeds planted by Van Halen (the band, not just the man). Eddie gets a chapter in that history book. In comparing their playing I would say that Slash was more fluid. He sticks closely to standard pentatonic scales and runs. Taken as a body of work, they’re more melodic — you can hum them more easily than Eddie’s. His tone is simple: Les Paul, Marshall, an occasional wah pedal. Eddie’s playing is tonally much more complicated. He doesn’t stick to strict pentatonic scales or runs. Dive bombs, feedback, pinched and tapped harmonics, custom/accidentally overdriven amplifier, chorus, flanger, phase… Eddie chased his “Brown Sound” and was more of a “tone junky” than Slash. There is no Cathedral or Intruder in Slash’s catalog. Eddie’s rhythm playing is also distinct from Slash’s. Eddie is famous for playing fast solos, tapping, and tremolo picking but his rhythm playing is as distinctive. Mean Street is a great all-encompassing example: That intro is pure Eddie. No one else plays like that. Note that this is actually a pretty bluesy intro.From about 29 seconds in we get a feel for the rhythm he’s playing. It has a funk feel that has Eddie written all over it.Eddie played both rhythm and lead. So he’s got to carry the main riff throughout the song. But when he’s not playing that riff, he’s quite happy leaving spaces between the notes. Or playing one chord/tone and letting it hang. He’s not racing anywhere.From 2:10 with the bridge, we hear a lot of these pieces come together: a bit of space, bit of a funk rhythm. We hear the Brown Sound.2:27 — a punch in from Eddie… oops.2:29 to 2:42 is a 13 second solo that says all it needs to, ending with a “broken” blues scale that settles on a vibrato blue note.3:20 simple volume swells — this is the “spoken word” portion of the song. Eddie does not need to be playing all the time.3:50 - he’s complementing the bass guitar and also carrying a bit of the melody.4:05 - outro solo where he’s bending into a tone.It’s clean, concise, a bit dynamically diverse. You might even listen to this isolated track and think, “that doesn’t sound that hard” because it’s not even fast. Slash’s solo in Paradise City is much faster. But it sounds easy because he’s that good.  Take another example: Spanish Fly. Eddie loved the sound of flamenco guitar but didn’t know how to play that style. So he composed a version of it. In concert he performs a partial, electric version in a montage with a bunch of other bits. So I’m linking to this cover by Rick Graham. Slash doesn’t play anything like this (I’m sure he can learn it) and I haven’t heard any composition that is that far away from his blues guitar style.  By now I’m sure it’s clear that I’m a Van Halen fan over Slash. But Slash is still a great player. He’s just more limited. And as much as he just isn’t as “out there” as Eddie, his solos were often much more composed and fluid. I am sure Eddie could play those tracks, but he didn’t compose anything like Fall to Pieces. fall to pieces - Bing video
